body: Me and my colleague @SebGr did a bit more investigation on this issue and it seems that this was issue was introduced in `1.9`. `mlflow==1.8` does not exhibit this behaviour.  `1.9` is also the version where `mlflow` started using the local backend config to pass the `run_id` to the databricks job instead of relying on the `--run-id` command line argument (as I'm proposing to revert to as a fix in #3788).

Ah I see. The problem is that these earlier versions of the ML runtime run mlflow <= 1.8.0. The backend_config which specifies `_MLFLOW_LOCAL_BACKEND_RUN_ID_CONFIG` is not backwards compatible to these earlier versions of MLflow. One possible fix is to both pass the backend config as well as `--run-id`.

If you would like to implement this, I would be happy to review. Otherwise, I can see if the engineering team at Databricks has the bandwidth.

Ahh, that explains a lot. Thank you so much for helping out here. We've been banging our head against this one for quite some time! I do feel that this is actually quite a tricky thing: the MLFlow version to start the run using the local backend is not the version specified in your projects `conda.yaml` or the version specified as the cluster dependency (as part of the submitted job). This now means that it is very easy to end up with a project where you have three different versions of MLFlow:

- The version of your client
- The version you specify in your projects `conda.yaml` and hence use to log
- The version that comes preinstalled on the databricks runtime (and basically serves as the "outer" mlflow version that is used to kick of a local run on the cluster).

I do think that this might be something that would be good to document a bit more (happy to submit an MR for that if you agree here), but also it might be better to just pin the version of MLFlow that is installed on the cluster level. Now if there is by default an older version of MLFlow on the runtime that is allowed, but I think it might be better to just pin the version to the same version as the client here: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/c7b5c5dd3ab7281f6fd9b0d44f78589353989b46/mlflow/projects/databricks.py#L199

That solves the issue of the "outer" MLFlow on databricks running a different version than the local client you are running locally and hence would prevent similar issues like this one in the future! I'm also happy to adjust the linked MR to implement the solution you proposed, but maybe this is a more generic solution. Let me know what you think.

Thanks for summarizing this so clearly! I think using the same version for `(2) The version you specify in your projects conda.yaml and hence use to log` and `(3) The version that comes preinstalled on the databricks runtime.` would reduce the cognitive overhead here.

Unfortunately, we would need this change to be backwards compatible. Meaning that MLProjects running against existing Databricks runtimes should continue to operate as-is, while new runtimes can fix the version of mlflow used in (3).

Another worry is that we may be breaking some use cases. @dbczumar @juntai-zheng @smurching is it common for a user to run an MLflow project against an MLflow backend, but want to use a different version of MLflow than that backend comes with?

I spoke with @smurching. Pinning the version of mlflow here
https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/c71bae2365177e57d7b50004c5b9964bd455bacc/mlflow/projects/databricks.py#L199
as you suggested sounds good. Though we will need to add some special logic to work around the issue described in that comment. Something like this pseudo-code:
```
if VERSION.ends_with('.dev0'):
  libraries = [{"pypi": {"package": "'mlflow<=%s'" % VERSION}}] 
else:
  libraries = [{"pypi": {"package": "'mlflow=%s'" % VERSION}}] 
```
Perfect! I've created an MR containing an implementation of these changes: #3880.

Wonderful! Thank you for fixing this point of confusion. I've LGTM'd and merged your pull request.

The PR auto-closed this Issue, but I'm actually going to re-open it. I believe that we still need to fix the run_id issue, perhaps by passing the backend config as well as --run-id.
